title: class based view vs Function based view

blocks.text: class based view vs Function based view
Django has two types of views; function-based views (FBVs), and class-based views (CBVs).
At their core, CBVs are Python classes. Django ships with a variety of “template” CBVs that have pre-configured functionality that you can reuse and oftentimes extend.

They are callable. A view can be either function or a class-based view. CBVs inherit the method as_view() which uses a dispatch() method to call the appropriate method depending on the HTTP verb (get, post, etc)
They must accept an HttpRequest object as its first positional argument
They must return an HttpResponse object or raise an exception.
For Login and Logout and password reset , we can use the inbuilt class based views offered by Django:
from users import views as user_views
#this is when you click on password reset option
#this is when you submit with the email
#this is for the url you receive in the email
For application CRUD operation we can use generic view and the mixins

when we use generic views , django look for some template by the pre-defined names (<app>/<model>_<viewtype>.html) or if you want it to look for specific template you need to supply template_name inside the view.
If you wish to render a form in the template, we need to use the naming convention model_form.html i.e. post_form.html
We can use mixins to limit undesired actions
LoginRequiredMixin - to make sure that user logs in before being able to access particular pages.
UserPassesTestMixin- to make user pass certain tests before being able to perform few actions.
here, we need to write a method tests_func
post = self.get_object()  # this will get the post we are trying to update
DetailView - blog/post_detail.html #lists a details of a particular post
CreateView - blog/post_form.html # if you want to render a form

UpdateView - blog/post_list.html #updates a particular post # if you want to render a form and pop it with the already 
                                                                                                                    existing data and then update it
POST with invalid data (typically redisplay form with errors)
POST with valid data (process the data and typically redirect)
